intro: Arabis nudicaulis, commonly known as the naked-stemmed rockcress, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its basal rosette of lance-shaped, hairy leaves and produces clusters of small, white or pale yellow flowers in early spring. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often in alpine or subalpine environments. It is a perennial species that is well adapted to cold climates and can tolerate harsh environmental conditions. The flowers are pollinated by insects, and the plant is of interest to botanists and gardeners for its ornamental value and ecological significance.
